clinical_study.official_title: Testing 'VOLITION' - a Randomised Feasibility Trial of a New Intervention: To Facilitate the inVolvement of OLder Patients With multimorbidITy in decisION-making About Their Healthcare During General Practice Consultations

collaborator.agency: National Institute for Health Research, United Kingdom

brief_summary.textblock:
Trial Design
A cluster randomised controlled feasibility trial with parallel qualitative interviews; to test a new intervention to be delivered in UK general practice.
Trial Participants
Patients aged 65 years and above with more than one long-term health problem (multimorbidity); and the GPs that these patients consult with.
Planned Sample Size
6 GP practices; 18 GPs; 180 patients
Treatment duration
2 weeks (delivery of patient and GP components of intervention)
Follow up duration
12 weeks (from index consultation and initial data collection to final case note review and completion of data collection)
Planned Trial Period 01/06/20 - 30/06/21; 1 year 30 days
Objectives
Primary
To feasibility test a new intervention 'VOLITION', with a view to informing the design of a fully-powered clinical trial to assess its effectiveness in routine clinical care.
Secondary
The development of a new intervention 'VOLITION': To facilitate the involvement of older patients with more than one long-term health problem, in joint decision-making about their healthcare, during GP consultations.
The Intervention 'VOLITION':
- half-day training workshop for GPs in shared decision-making
- written involvement-facilitating tool for patients (delivered by post and available in the waiting room).

detailed_description.textblock:
Design
A cluster randomised controlled feasibility trial with parallel qualitative interviews.
Trial setting and participants
In order to achieve sociodemographic diversity in the participant sample, and to ensure generalisability of the results, the investigators aim to recruit six GP practices; from across rural Devon as well as from each of the cities of Exeter and Plymouth, UK. The minimum practice size will be 3,000 patients.
The investigators aim to recruit an average of three, and at least two, GPs per practice (total = 18 GPs). Only permanent GPs will be included to avoid possible loss to follow up when recruiting locum GPs, however GPs will not be excluded based on less than full time equivalent working hours. The investigators will review the external validity of the sample by comparing to relevant external datasets when reporting recruitment, selection procedures and participation rates.
Patients aged 65 and above with known multimorbidity, defined as the presence of two or more long-term conditions, will be approached. The investigators will not specify a minimum time to be 'long-term', however the condition should be one of: Angina or long-term heart problem; arthritis or long-term joint problem; asthma or long-term chest problem; blindness or severe visual impairment; cancer in the last five years; deafness or severe hearing impairment; diabetes; epilepsy; high blood pressure; kidney or liver disease; long-term back problem; long-term mental health problem; long-term neurological problem. This list was adapted from the English National General Practice Patient Survey , however the Quality and Outcomes Framework indicators of long-term conditions will also be considered in order to identify potential participants on practice computer systems. Where dyads of conditions occur within the same organ system, e.g. anxiety and depression, these will only be counted once e.g. mental health problem.
Potential patient participants will be identified using an automated algorithm via the practice computer system resulting in a 'flag' on patient notes visible to practice staff; approximately 800 'flagged' patients in an average 8,000 patient practice. The practice administration team will use this 'flag' to identify ten consecutive potential participants with pre-booked consultations with each of the three recruited GPs (total = 180 patients). These appointments will ideally all be booked on the same day but may span two working days. The investigators will aim to recruit at least half of these patients and will not approach temporary residents. The sample size has been justified in order to provide effect estimates for the primary outcome.
Vulnerable patients will be identified by the GP and will be excluded from participation in the study. Reasons for exclusion will be documented. The presence of carers or third parties within the index consultation will be explored during the analysis of consultation data.
Recruitment
Non-compliance with all elements of the intervention, at patient, GP or practice level, will be taken into account by over-recruiting. Numbers lost to follow up will be reviewed, with consideration given to incentivising participants in the future trial if necessary. However, it is anticipated that loss to follow up will be minimal.
Practices will receive an initial letter and follow-up telephone call. Practices will be offered a visit at which information will be provided regarding the trial, timeline, and staff involvement. Evidence suggests that GPs are more likely to agree to intervention studies when they have an interest in the topic, when they believe it will not take too much time, and when they appreciate the 'Continuing Professional Development' associated with participation. The investigators hope to recruit GPs by highlighting these issues in the letter to practices and when contacting individuals by email.
For each recruited GP, ten consecutive potential participants, with pre-booked consultations, will be contacted by post ahead of their appointment. These patients will receive a cover letter on practice headed paper, a participant information sheet, a consent form and a pre-consultation questionnaire. Patients will be asked to return their questionnaire to the research team in a pre-paid stamped addressed envelope ahead of their consultation. Patients will be asked to complete the consent form and to bring it along to their consultation with the GP so that the GP can confirm consent prior to data collection.
Randomisation
The investigators plan to use a cluster randomised design in the future full-scale trial. Clusters will be defined at practice level with randomisation following practice recruitment, to usual care or to the intervention. Although statistically more powerful, randomising by patient would be impractical and vulnerable to contamination. In order to evaluate randomisation procedures, to compare the feasibility of potential outcome measures in both intervention and control groups, and to compare feasibility measures across different types of practice, we will cluster randomise using block randomisation in the feasibility study. Block randomisation will be stratified by site; two practices in inner city Plymouth, two practices from Exeter and two from rural Devon.
In order to reduce bias, practice randomisation on a 1:1 allocation (90 patients per arm) will be conducted using computer allocation software by an independent statistician. Blinding of the research team will not be possible for the purposes of this feasibility study due to resource availability. Participants will be informed via participant information sheets that their practice will either be assigned to intervention or to control. Participants in the intervention arm are likely to be aware that they are receiving more than the standard 'usual care'. The investigators will report comparisons in pre- and post-intervention data between the control and intervention groups when analysing results. The sample size if sufficient to compare standard deviations in the primary outcome between the intervention and control group.
Consent
Initial consent to identify and approach potential patient participants will be obtained from the practice manager. Written consent to participate will be obtained from individual GPs. Patients will be asked to complete consent forms received in the post prior to attending for their consultation with the GP, however patients will be asked to bring their consent forms with them to their consultation and GPs will be asked to confirm this consent at the beginning of the consultation. GPs will also have spare consent forms available. Practice administration staff will carry out the task of approaching patients; the research team will not have access to personal information or patient notes without prior consent from patients themselves. Written consent from patients will be obtained for video-recording of the consultation. Consent for case note review, and to be approached for subsequent process evaluation interviews, will also be confirmed by the GP at the end of the consultation.
The intervention
The intervention will incorporate a training workshop for GPs in the use of shared decision-making surrounding an index consultation, and a written involvement-facilitating tool for patients attending an index consultation with these GPs.
Data collection
Data will be collected in both intervention and control groups.
Descriptive measures: Core data will be collected in respect of participating practices (list size, location and deprivation), patients (age, gender, ethnicity, health status), the GPs with whom they consult (age, gender, ethnicity, time since qualification), and regarding practices (practice size, staffing, rural/urban).
Process measures: The flow of practices and participants will be documented and summarised in a Consort diagram; numbers randomised, recruitment rates and participant attrition (see attached figures for blank template diagrams). The investigators will seek to understand whether data collection is feasible in the absence of the intervention and whether there are differential drop-out or recruitment rates between intervention and control groups.
Patient reported outcome measures (PROMs): The investigators have previously found that the General Practice Patient Survey (GPPS), which uses five-point Likert scales, lends itself well to the evaluation of PROMs. A subset of the GPPS will be used in the pre-consultation patient questionnaire. The questionnaire will also include an item regarding patients' preferences for involvement in decision-making. Patients who do not wish to participate in the study, or to receive further contact, will be asked to indicate this with a tick box and to return their otherwise blank pre-consultation questionnaire in a prepaid envelope. A post-consultation questionnaire will be given to the patient by the GP. With this questionnaire we patients will be asked for feedback following the index consultation, including patient satisfaction with the healthcare received, the extent to which they felt engaged in decision-making about their healthcare, and a measure of patient empowerment. A tick box on the post-consultation questionnaire will be a means for patients to opt out of process evaluation interviews and/or from having their case notes reviewed.
GP data collection will consist of a single item on patient consent forms. At the end of the consultation, the GP will re-confirm the patient's consent and they will also rate the extent to which they engaged the patient in decision-making. These ratings will be compared with patient ratings.
Following consent from patients and GPs, video-recordings will be made of the index consultation. These recordings will enable the shared decision-making process to be assessed from an observer perspective using the OPTION scale. If multiple decisions are made, decisions will be rated separately. It is thought that an average of 2.5 problems are discussed between a patient and GP per consultation. Rates of consent to video-recording will be evaluated as part of this study. It is thought that video-recording may cause bias in the characteristics of doctors and patients who agree to participate in research, however there is little evidence that it influences the behaviour of either GPs or patients. Video recordings will also capture the nature of the index problem.
Case note review for 30 consenting patients will take place twelve weeks after initial consultation, to gather information regarding re-attendance within 28 days, whether the patient was referred for an investigation, and whether the patient was referred to see a specialist in secondary care, following the index consultation. The investigators will seek to stratify the case notes review in order to include data from under-represented groups e.g. males and the oldest patients. Two researchers will carry out case notes review and inter-rater reliability will be assessed on the data. Data will be encrypted (as per NHS security requirements) and recorded electronically.
Process evaluation to support feasibility objectives
A qualitative interview study running alongside the feasibility trial with data integration.
Process evaluation will take a sequential-explanatory approach, combining deductive and inductive methods to investigate whether the theory developed earlier in the fellowship holds, but also being open to new data/themes emerging.

Although statistically more powerful, randomising by patient would be impractical and vulnerable to contamination. We will cluster randomise using block randomisation. Block randomisation will be stratified by site; two practices in inner city Plymouth, two practices from Exeter and two from rural Devon. In order to reduce bias, practice randomisation on a 1:1 allocation (90 patients per arm) will be conducted using computer allocation software by an independent statistician. We will report comparisons in pre- and post-intervention data between the control and intervention groups when analysing results. The sample size if sufficient to compare standard deviations in our primary outcome between the intervention and control group.
study_design_info.masking_description: Blinding of the research team will not be possible for the purposes of this feasibility study due to resource availability. Participants will be informed via participant information sheets that their practice will either be assigned to intervention or to control. Participants will not be informed which arm of the study their practice has been randomised to, however participants in the intervention arm are likely to be aware that they are receiving more than the standard 'usual care'.

primary_outcome.time_frame: At two to four weeks post-index consultation.
primary_outcome.description: Two observers rate video-recorded consultations using the OPTION5 scale (Elwyn 2017), a measure of shared decision-making. Five elements of GP-patient communication are rated, the scores are summed, and converted to a percentage to provide an overall score (0-100) for each GP consultation. Higher scores indicate greater patient involvement in decision-making about their healthcare.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient and GP ratings of shared decision-making
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to one week; for completion immediately after index consultation.
secondary_outcome.description: Assessment of shared decision-making from both GP and patient perspectives. Questionnaires completed on the day of index consultation, immediately following the consultation. One questionnaire per patient participant, taking approximately 10 minutes to complete. Participants are asked to rate their perceptions of shared decision-making on a 5-point likert scale with higher scores indicating greater perceived involvement.

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient re-attendance within 28 days of the index consultation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Notes reviewed at 12 weeks after index consultation (the 12 weeks allows for data entry into notes to 'settle' in order to retrieve accurate data regarding both outcomes 3 and 5)
secondary_outcome.description: Case note review carried out by a researcher

secondary_outcome.measure: Patient enablement instrument following the index consultation
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Up to one week; for completion immediately after index consultation.
secondary_outcome.description: Measure of patient enablement embedded in post-consultation patient questionnaire. Ratings completed following index consultations (10 minute consultation per patient participant). Questionnaires completed on the day of index consultation, immediately following the consultation. One questionnaire per patient participant, taking approximately 10 minutes to complete. Elements of patient enablement are rated on a three point likert scale with greater enablement receiving a higher score. Maximum score of 12, minimum score of 0, per consultation.

secondary_outcome.measure: Rates of referral and investigation following the index consultation
secondary_outcome.description: Case note review carried out by a researcher

arm_group.description: VOLITION: Two intervention components; one targeted at patients and one at GPs.
Usual care: GP consults with patient as per usual care.

intervention.description: The intervention will incorporate a training workshop for GPs in the use of shared decision-making surrounding an index consultation, and a written involvement-facilitating tool for patients attending an index consultation with these GPs. Evaluation will focus around the index consultation between participating patients and GPs. The intervention outcomes will be compared with 'usual care' in the control group. A written decision-support tool may include simple bullet points prompting the patient to ask to be involved in decision-making when visiting a GP, with examples of the phrases to use. The tool will be mailed to the 'flagged' potential patient participants along with their patient information pack, ahead of the index consultation, and it will also be available in the waiting room.

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion criteria:
- GP practice located in Devon, UK
- GP participants must be permanent practice employees
- Patient participants must be aged 65 and above with multimorbidity
Exclusion criteria:
- Previous participation in the focus group study to refine the intervention
- Locum GPs
- Trainee GPs and junior doctors working in general practice
- Temporarily registered patients
- Vulnerable patients (as screened by usual GP)
